chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of constipation in children
chapter.summary: Covers the management of idiopathic constipation in children.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth to 18 years.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a child with idiopathic constipation in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Treat a child for constipation in primary care only if a working diagnosis of idiopathic constipation has been made and red flags have been excluded. Liaise with other members of the primary care multidisciplinary team, if necessary, such as the health visitor or school health adviser.

  • Assess for the presence of amber flags and if present, refer for further specialist assessment, the urgency depending on clinical judgement.
  • If there is evidence of perianal streptococcal infection, treat for constipation and also treat the infection.
  • Give information and advice to the child and/or their parents/carers:
    • Reassure that underlying causes of constipation have been excluded by the history and physical examination.
    • Advise that idiopathic constipation is treatable with laxatives, although they may need to be taken for several months.
    • Offer sources of information and support — leaflets are available from the NHS, Patient UK, and the Children's Bowel & Bladder Charity ERIC. ERIC also runs a helpline (telephone 0845 370 8008).
  • Check for faecal impaction and if present, treat using a recommended disimpaction regimen.
  • Start maintenance laxative drug treatment if impaction is not present or has been successfully treated.
  • Offer advice on behavioural interventions for children started on maintenance laxative drug treatment. The intervention should be consistent with the child's age and stage of development and may include:
    • Scheduled toileting — encourage the child to try and open their bowels at pre-planned intervals or activities, such as after each meal for five minutes, or before bedtime.
    • Use of a bowel habit diary — to track the frequency and consistency of stool. The ERIC Toilet Tool Wallchart may be helpful.
    • Use of encouragement and rewards systems — such as star charts incorporated into toileting routines, to help praise good behaviour such as visiting the toilet.
  • Give diet and lifestyle advice and information on recommended fluid intake if needed, in combination with advice on the early use of laxatives and behavioural interventions.
  • Follow up the child regularly to assess adherence and response to treatment, and to advise on when to reduce and stop laxatives.
  • Consider the need for specialist referral.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Diet and lifestyle advice
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Recommend a balanced diet with sufficient fibre (in all children who have been weaned).

  • Foods with a high fibre content include fruit, vegetables, high-fibre bread, baked beans, and wholegrain breakfast cereals.
    • Do not recommend unprocessed bran (which may cause bloating and flatulence and reduces the absorption of micronutrients) or fibre supplements.
    • Written advice on a healthy diet is available from UK Association of Dietitians.
  • Do not switch formula feed or start a cows' milk exclusion diet unless advised by specialist services. For more information, see the CKS topic on Cows' milk protein allergy in children.
  • Advise normal daily physical activity that is tailored to the child or young person's stage of development and ability.
    • Physical activity guidelines for different age groups are available from the UK Chief Medical Officer.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Recommended fluid intake
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Encourage children with poor fluid intake to increase fluids to a recommended level.

  • Approximately three-quarters of the daily fluid requirement in children is obtained from water in drinks. Higher intakes of total water will be required for children who are physically active, exposed to hot environments, or obese.
  • The following is a guide to adequate total water intake per day, including water contained in food. It should not be interpreted as a specific requirement:
    • Infants 0–6 months of age: 700 mL, assumed to be from milk.
    • Babies 7–12 months of age: 800 mL from milk and complementary foods and beverages, of which 600 mL is assumed to be water from drinks.
    • Children 1–3 years of age: 1300 mL (900 mL from drinks).
    • Children 4–8 years of age: 1700 mL (1200 mL from drinks).
    • Children 9–13 years of age:
      • Boys — 2400 mL (1800 mL from drinks).
      • Girls — 2100 mL (1600 mL from drinks).
    • Young people 14–18 years of age:
      • Boys — 3300 mL (2600 mL from drinks).
      • Girls — 2300 mL (1800 mL from drinks).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of constipation are largely based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Constipation in children and young people: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2017] and the previous, full guideline from which this was developed [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010]. They are also supported by a literature review and expert opinion in the European and North American clinical guideline Evaluation and treatment of functional constipation in infants and children: evidence-based recommendations from ESPGHAN and NASPGHAN [Tabbers, 2014].

Information and advice
  • The recommendation on giving information and advice to the child and their family/carers is based on the NICE guideline that highlights that the level of information and support given can play a significant role in the effectiveness and success of constipation management regimes, help to empower children and their family/carers, and increase their involvement in all aspects of their care.
Advice on behavioural interventions
  • The recommendations on behavioural interventions are based on the experience and opinion of the NICE guideline development group (GDG) and on expert opinion in the review article Childhood Constipation [Auth, 2012].
Diet and lifestyle advice
  • The NICE GDG felt that poor diet alone is rarely the cause of childhood constipation, and noted that treatment with laxatives is sometimes delayed while dietary and lifestyle adjustments are made, which may worsen constipation. It advocated that any changes in diet should be made alongside laxative treatment and possible behavioural interventions, and that dietary interventions alone should not be used as first-line treatment for idiopathic constipation.
  • The NICE GDG found no evidence that increasing fibre-rich foods, such as fruit, vegetables, and cereals, is effective in managing constipation in children who eat a healthy balanced diet. Excessive dietary fibre may exacerbate symptoms and increase the risk of soiling, and both the NICE guideline and the ESPGHAN/NASPGHAN clinical guideline found insufficient evidence to recommend fibre supplements, such as prune and fig concentrate, for the treatment of constipation in children and young people.
  • The NICE guideline states that there is no good-quality evidence for the effectiveness of increasing physical activity to improve constipation, but as physical inactivity may be a contributory factor in constipation, regular exercise should be encouraged as it may reduce the likelihood of a relapse in constipation in the future.
Recommended fluid intake
  • NICE found one open-label randomized controlled trial that showed that increasing fluid intake did not have a significant impact on stool frequency, consistency, or difficulty passing stools in children with constipation, compared with controls who did not increase fluid intake. The NICE GDG concluded that achieving recommended levels of fluid intake is important, as dehydration may be worsened by the use of osmotic laxatives, but there is no evidence for advising increased fluid intake beyond recommended levels.
  • A subsequent NICE evidence update also reported limited evidence suggesting that raising fluid intake above normal has no effect [NICE, 2012].
  • The recommendations on fluid intake for different age groups are derived from expert opinion in the National Academy of Sciences guideline Dietary reference intakes for water, potassium, sodium, chloride, and sulfate [Institute of Medicine of the National Academies, 2005].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I treat faecal impaction?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the child and/or their parents/carers that treating impaction can initially increase symptoms of soiling and abdominal pain, and ensure the child has easy access to a toilet.
  • Offer the following oral laxative regimen, and review all children undergoing disimpaction within 1 week:
    • Prescribe a macrogol (Movicol® Paediatric Plain or Movicol® depending on the child's age) first-line, using an escalating dose regimen. Ensure that an effective dose is used, and adjust the dose according to symptoms and response. It is unflavoured, but fruit squash may be added if preferred to improve adherence.
      • If this fails to lead to disimpaction after 2 weeks, add a stimulant laxative (such as senna).
      • Note: the use of Movicol® Paediatric Plain to treat faecal impaction in children younger than 5 years of age is off-label. In addition, laxative doses above the licensed maximum dose may be needed. Informed consent should be verbally obtained and documented in these circumstances.
    • If the macrogol is not tolerated, substitute a stimulant laxative (such as senna) either on its own or, if stools are hard, in combination with lactulose or another stool softener laxative, such as docusate.
      • For information on contraindications, doses, and adverse effects of laxatives, see the section on Prescribing information.
  • Consider seeking specialist advice or arranging urgent referral if all oral laxative regimens have failed, or the child is very distressed.
    • Do not routinely use suppositories or enemas in primary care.
  • Start maintenance laxative treatment as soon as the bowel is disimpacted.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on faecal disimpaction treatments are largely based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Constipation in children and young people: diagnosis and management  [NICE, 2017] and the previous, full guideline from which this was developed [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010]. They are also supported by a literature review and expert opinion in the European and North American clinical guideline Evaluation and treatment of functional constipation in infants and children: evidence-based recommendations from ESPGHAN and NASPGHAN [Tabbers, 2014].

First-line disimpaction regimen
  • The recommendations on the first-line use of an oral macrogol for disimpaction are based on moderate-quality case series, small low-quality randomized controlled trials, and the experience and opinion of the NICE guideline development group (GDG) [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010].
    • Movicol® Paediatric Plain is licensed for disimpaction in children older than 5 years of age [ABPI, 2020a; BNF for Children, 2020]. NICE concluded that it is safe and effective in infants younger than 1 year of age, but evidence is limited to small case series. The NICE GDG also noted that it is associated with fewer adverse effects and is more palatable than other laxatives, and is easy to titrate and use at home.
    • Movicol® Paediatric Plain is the only electrolyte-containing macrogol licensed for children younger than 12 years of age [ABPI, 2020a], but it does not have UK marketing authorization for use in faecal impaction in children younger than 5 years of age, or for chronic constipation in children younger than 1 year of age. Informed consent from a parent or carer should therefore be obtained and documented when prescribing for children in these age groups.
Second-line oral laxatives
  • The recommendation on prescribing second-line stimulant laxatives and adding a stool softener laxative (such as lactulose or docusate) if needed are based on the experience and expert opinion of the NICE GDG as there was a lack of evidence for the effectiveness of stimulant laxatives in disimpaction [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010].
Use of suppositories or enemas in primary care
  • The recommendation on the use of suppositories or enemas in primary care is based on the expert opinion of the NICE GDG, which states that although enemas are effective for rectal disimpaction, the administration route is uncomfortable for children. They should only be used when all oral treatments have failed. If needed, sodium citrate enemas are preferred as phosphate enemas have more adverse effects and should only be used under specialist supervision.
  • A NICE evidence update also found that macrogols have similar efficacy compared with rectal enemas in the treatment of faecal disimpaction [NICE, 2012], this is supported by the ESPGHAN/NASPGHAN clinical guideline [Tabbers, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I prescribe maintenance laxatives for children (including after disimpaction)?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If faecal impaction is present, see the section on Faecal disimpaction treatment.
  • If impaction is not present or has been treated, start maintenance laxative treatment promptly (even if constipation is reported for only a few days), aiming for regular soft formed stools. Ensure the child has easy access to a toilet.
    • Prescribe a macrogol (Movicol® Paediatric Plain or Movicol® depending on the child's age) first-line, using an escalating dose regimen. Ensure that an effective dose is used, and adjust the dose according to response to treatment. It is unflavoured, but fruit squash may be added if preferred to improve adherence.
      • If the child required disimpaction, the usual maintenance dose is half the disimpaction dose.
      • If constipation persists despite optimal doses of the macrogol, add a stimulant laxative (such as senna).
      • If diarrhoea occurs, reduce the dose of laxative(s) as prolonged diarrhoea can cause electrolyte disturbances, including hypokalaemia.
      • Note: the use of Movicol® Paediatric Plain to treat chronic constipation in children younger than 2 years of age is off-label. In addition, laxative doses above the licensed maximum dose may be needed. Informed consent should be verbally obtained and documented in these circumstances.
    • If the macrogol is not tolerated, substitute a stimulant laxative (such as senna) and, if stools are hard, consider combining with lactulose or another stool softener laxative, such as docusate.
      • For information on contraindications, doses, and adverse effects of laxatives, see the section on Prescribing information.
  • Continue the effective dose of laxative(s) for at least several weeks after regular bowel movements are established, aiming for a soft regular formed stool. This may take several months to achieve.
  • Consider seeking specialist advice or arranging referral if all oral laxative treatments have failed.
    • Do not routinely use suppositories or enemas in primary care for maintenance treatment.
  • Arrange regular follow up, the frequency depending on clinical judgement, to advise about gradually reducing and stopping laxatives.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of constipation are largely based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Constipation in children and young people: diagnosis and management  [NICE, 2017] and the previous, full guideline from which this was developed [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010].

Maintenance laxative treatment
  • The recommendations on maintenance laxative treatment are largely based on low-quality evidence from 14 randomized controlled trials (RCTs; seven open-label, six double-blind, and one single-blind) and one prospective cohort study, and on the expertise and experience of the NICE guideline development group (GDG) [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010].
Assessing for faecal impaction
  • The NICE GDG states that unless children with faecal impaction receive treatment for disimpaction beforehand, even optimal maintenance laxative treatment will be ineffective and could exacerbate the symptoms of constipation [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010].
Early use of laxatives
  • The recommendation to start laxative treatment promptly is based on the NICE guideline and a subsequent evidence update [NICE, 2012], and on the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic. The reviewers highlighted that early use of laxatives is valuable, even if the child has been constipated for only a few days, to prevent longer-term problems of chronic constipation, and because often the child would have been constipated for longer than suggested by the history. The NICE evidence update also supports the assertion that early identification and treatment of childhood constipation can improve outcomes.
First-line oral laxatives
  • The recommendation on using Movicol® Paediatric Plain first-line for maintenance treatment is based on a meta-analysis of high-quality RCTs, additional high-quality RCTs, high-quality observational studies, and the experience and expert opinion of the NICE GDG.
    • The GDG acknowledged that evidence was not available for the full range of laxative treatment options and that many drugs are used in practice on the basis of years of clinical experience, but have not been formally tested in clinical trials in children. NICE recommends the initial use of a macrogol as monotherapy because it works quickly, is easy to titrate, is well tolerated, and the flavour of the child's favourite drink can be added to improve adherence.
    • NICE found evidence that laxatives are effective in children younger than 1 year of age, but this was limited to case series. It recommends that many children younger than 1 year of age need an early diagnosis of constipation and usually require medication to prevent potential long-term complications.
    • Movicol® Paediatric Plain is the only macrogol licensed for chronic constipation in children younger than 12 years of age [ABPI, 2020a], but it does not have UK marketing authorization in children younger than 2 years of age [BNF for Children, 2020]. Informed consent from a parent or carer should therefore be obtained and documented when prescribing for children in this age group.
Second-line oral laxatives
  • The recommendations on prescribing second-line stimulant laxatives and adding a stool softener laxative (such as lactulose or docusate) if needed are based on evidence from low-quality RCTs identified by NICE, and the experience and expert opinion of the NICE GDG.
Duration of maintenance treatment
  • The recommendations on the duration and gradual reduction of maintenance treatment are based on the experience and expert opinion of the NICE GDG. Expert opinion from previous external reviewers of this CKS topic was that although the duration of laxative treatment might be shorter in children with a very short history of constipation, laxatives should still be continued until a regular bowel pattern is achieved, and the child carefully monitored when reducing and stopping treatment to ensure that a relapse of constipation does not occur.
Use of suppositories or enemas in primary care
  • The recommendation on not routinely using suppositories or enemas in primary care is based on the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic, who stated that it is not advisable to use rectal medication in primary care unless healthcare professionals with a special interest are available in the community.
  • A NICE evidence update suggests that macrogols have similar efficacy compared with rectal enemas in maintenance treatment for constipation, although enemas were negatively perceived by some children [NICE, 2012].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What follow up should I arrange for a child with constipation?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange regular follow up to assess adherence and response to treatment.
    • Provide a consistent approach to follow up and make an individualized plan according to the child's response to treatment.
    • Liaise with other members of the primary care multidisciplinary team, if necessary, such as the health visitor or school health adviser.
  • At follow-up review:
    • Address any precipitating factors (which may affect response to treatment, and to reduce the risk of recurrent constipation) such as poor diet, insufficient fluid intake, or psychosocial factors.
    • Check the child's adherence to disimpaction and maintenance laxative treatment regimes.
    • Consider using the Bristol Stool Form Scale to measure the frequency, amount, and consistency of stools in order to assess the response to treatment. Aim for regular soft formed stools.
    • Ensure the child does not become re-impacted — if present, see the section on Faecal disimpaction treatment.
    • Advise on how to gradually reduce the maintenance laxative dose over a period of months once regular bowel movements are established, to maintain stool consistency and frequency. Advise that:
      • Laxative treatment should not be stopped abruptly.
      • Children who are toilet training should remain on laxatives until toilet training is well established.
      • If a combination of laxatives has been prescribed, reduce and stop one laxative at a time, if possible.
      • A shorter duration of laxative treatment may be possible in some children with a very short history of constipation, but they should be carefully monitored for a relapse of constipation.
      • Some children may require laxative treatment for several years, and a minority require ongoing treatment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on follow up of a child with constipation are largely based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Constipation in children and young people: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2017] and the previous, full guideline from which this was developed [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010].

Using the Bristol Stool Form Scale
  • The recommendation to consider using the Bristol Stool Form Scale to assess the stool is based on the fact that it can aid clinical communication between healthcare professionals and help assess the effectiveness of treatment at follow up, by classifying different types of faeces by consistency and form into seven categories [Auth, 2012].
Reducing one laxative at a time
  • The recommendation to reduce one laxative at a time if a combination has been used is based on expert opinion in the clinical guideline Therapeutic notes on the management of chronic constipation in primary care [COMPASS, 2016].
Duration of maintenance treatment
  • The recommendations on the duration and gradual reduction of maintenance treatment are based on the experience and expert opinion of the NICE guideline development group. Expert opinion from previous external reviewers of this CKS topic was that although the duration of laxative treatment might be shorter in children with a very short history of constipation, laxatives should still be continued until a regular bowel pattern is achieved, and the child carefully monitored when reducing and stopping treatment to ensure that a relapse of constipation does not occur.

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a child with constipation?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Consider arranging hospital admission if the child has persisting faecal impaction despite optimal faecal disimpaction treatment, or if the child is very distressed.
  • Arrange specialist referral if there are:
    • Any red flags — urgent referral to exclude a serious underlying cause or condition.
      • Do not initiate treatment for constipation in primary care.
    • Any amber flags — the urgency depending on clinical judgement.
      • Treatment for constipation can be initiated in primary care whilst awaiting specialist assessment.
  • Consider arranging specialist referral if the child is not responding to maintenance laxative treatment in primary care:
    • If younger than 1 year of age and no response to laxatives after 4 weeks — refer urgently to a clinician competent to perform a digital rectal examination to exclude Hirschsprung's disease or other underlying pathology.
    • If older than 1 year of age and no response to laxatives after 3 months — refer to a practitioner with appropriate expertise, such as a paediatrician or specialist nurse-led children's continence service.
    • See the section on Secondary care management for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Secondary care management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Specialist management of constipation that does not respond to optimal treatment in primary care may include:
    • Manual evacuation of the bowel under anaesthesia (if all oral and rectal medications have failed).
    • Use of polyethylene glycol solutions for whole-gut lavage (often via nasogastric tube).
    • Antegrade colonic enema (a surgical procedure).
    • Psychological and behavioural interventions, ranging from toilet training to family therapy.
    • Referral to child and adolescent mental health services for psychological issues — may be of value if psychological distress relates to the symptoms of constipation or there are family difficulties that maintain or exacerbate constipation.

[National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on referral and secondary care management are largely based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Constipation in children and young people: diagnosis and management [NICE, 2017] and the previous, full guideline from which this was developed [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010].

  • In addition, a review article states that hospital referral may be needed for disimpaction if optimal laxative treatment in primary care has been unsuccessful [Auth, 2012].
  • If a child has red flag symptoms or signs, an urgent referral is needed as further specialist tests may be required, such as rectal biopsy if Hirschsprung's disease is suspected.
  • If a child has amber flag symptoms or signs, or ongoing constipation that has not responded to optimal laxative treatment in primary care, specialist referral is needed to consider further tests for underlying conditions, such as coeliac disease and hypothyroidism.
  • The NICE guideline development group concluded that evidence on psychological interventions for the treatment of chronic constipation was very limited. Psychological problems are much more likely to be secondary to the symptoms of constipation rather than the cause. Referral for psychological intervention may be of benefit where there is psychological distress related to the symptoms of constipation and/or family difficulties that maintain or exacerbate constipation.
  • NICE therefore recommends against routine referral of children and young people with idiopathic constipation to a psychologist or child and adolescent mental health services unless they are likely to benefit from receiving a psychological intervention [NICE, 2017].
